## VIEW OF RAW DATA 
```{r,view raw data}
#LATEST DATA
corona_individual <- read.csv("latestdata.csv")
#dimesion of data
dim(corona_individual)
#column names
colnames(corona_individual)
#structure of data
str(corona_individual)
#omitting NA values
corona_individual=na.omit(corona_individual)
dim(corona_individual)
```
#Age
```{r,age}
ageColumn <- corona_individual$age
length(ageColumn)
ageColumn_Unique <- unique(ageColumn)
ageColumn_Unique
summary(corona_individual$age)
corona_individual$age <- as.numeric(corona_individual$age)
### OUTLIERS https://rpubs.com/Mentors_Ubiqum/removing_outliers
boxplot(corona_individual$age, col= "orange")
outliers <- boxplot(corona_individual$age, plot=FALSE)$out

# First you need find in which rows the outliers are
corona_individual[which(corona_individual$age %in% outliers),]

# Now you can remove the rows containing the outliers, one possible option is:
corona_individual <- corona_individual[-which(corona_individual$age %in% outliers),]

# If you check now with boxplot, you will notice that those pesky outliers are gone
boxplot(corona_individual$age, col= "orange")
#corona_individual <- corona_individual[between(corona_individual$age, 1, 100),]
#boxplot(corona_individual$age)
#meanAge=mean(corona_individual$age,na.rm=T)
meanAge=mean(corona_individual$age,na.rm=T)
corona_individual$age=ifelse(is.na(corona_individual$age),meanAge,corona_individual$age)
#boxplot(corona_individual$age)
summary(corona_individual$age)
```
